instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.TPS62180: What is TPS62180? This is a power chip responsible for many different power rails on 2016-2020 Macbook Pros,  most often known as the SSD buck converter chip responsible for NAND power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
Mac was liquid damage but the board is clean, the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on this board are underfilled so no liquid got under them and all other components around the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips look clean. I tried restoring the T2 firmware and also read this post: [url]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/56483-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-20v[/url] but I cannot get the board to go into DFU mode and when I try to put it into restore mode nothing happens.

ppbus 12v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.019v

At one point one of the ports boot loop but only one time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message: Also when I connect the charger in all 4 ports only 2 of them put out 5v to <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.019v"
There is a problem.
Do you get this voltage on two USB-C ports only?
Looks like you have problems in USB-C area, if you don't have the same behaviour on all ports...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
Yes with 2 of the 4 ports I get [COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]5v on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> with the other 2 I get 0v, and with all 4 ports I get[COLOR=#b00000]  0.019v on [/COLOR][/FONT][/COLOR][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

All 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> have underfilled and look clean all around them, the liquid did not do any damage or got to the board at all, only near the fan euxast area there was liquid, not sure how this board got to this state with no liquid damage.[/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Post <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.
Also good to know diode mode to ground at L6900/01.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
So you have 12.28V at F7000?
This could be T2 firmware issue.
Use search function on the forum and try to recover T2 firmware.

However, I'm not sure, as you don't get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> first, or check for corrosion on its area; especially <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
Yes I do have 12.2v on F7000.

Here is what I did to restore T2 firmware without success:

1. Mount board on a good top case with battery, connect power button, connect keyboard and trackpad connect/screw battery

2. If you are looking at the keyboard as if you were about to type I connected the charger and USB-C cable to the top left USB-C port

3. Also connected an USB-C Belkin cable on the USB-C port below that one, that same cable I connected to a 2016 15" MPB on the same port location but also tried the other port on the left side with no luck.

4. I opened up Apple Configurator App

5. Pressed and held down Power-Right Side Shift-Left Side Control and Option keys for more than 10 seconds.

But nothing happens on the Apple Configurator App.

About to do the rest you are suggesting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message: I don't have another <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> however I reballed it, <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>/13 are both good, I measured them off the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
"especially <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13"
Means <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>/11/12/13...
T2 needs <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> too.
This could be the reason of unsuccessful recover process.
Maybe no need to do that, once get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> back...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
Thanks, I just checked <RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>/12 both are good.

Diode mode on P3V3G3HRTC_PHASE1 is 388ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message: You led me to believe that <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> was the problem, so I found out that <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> is the same chip, so I just swaped them and boom got 20v! I now know that <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is the problem, time to get some of this chips in stock.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v taken not 20v
threads.message:
I got the <CHIP>TPS62180</CHIP> chips, replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>, restored T2 firmware and done, Mac is working and customer did not loose any data.

Thanks for your help, I made a few notes on this new MacBooks
